Document.TEXT:
Joseph P. Kennedy, FDR's ambassador to Britain, called her, admiringly, "a cute trick." Hitler, on the other hand, thought her charisma made her "the most dangerous woman in Europe." But it was society photographer Cecil Beaton who best summed up her place in the hearts of her subjects: "She is the great mother figure and nanny of us all."
In an outpouring of affection last week, the world bid Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, a fond farewell after the 101-year-old died peacefully in her sleep at Windsor's Royal Lodge on March 30, less than two months after the death of her younger daughter, Princess Margaret, at 71. The Queen Mother's health had taken a downturn at Christmas, when she caught a chest infection. Yet the legendary bon vivant rallied to host a party just three weeks before she died, donning a red cocktail dress and high heels and holding court for two hours with her horse-racing friends. By Easter Saturday, though, her body could no longer keep up with her spirit. Her daughter Queen Elizabeth II was called to her bedside, and in a room filled with the fragrance of a potted jasmine plant Prince Charles had given her for Easter, the Queen Mum died at 3:15 p.m, the younger Elizabeth holding her hand.
Prince Charles, who was skiing at the Swiss resort of Klosters with his sons, Princes William and Harry, flew back to England the next morning (the royal trio boarded the same jet, a rare breach of protocol for the heirs to the throne, sanctioned by the Queen). "For me, she meant everything, and I had dreaded, dreaded this moment," a teary Charles said in a televised tribute to his "darling grandmother" two days later. "Somehow I never thought it would come. She seemed gloriously unstoppable, and since I was a child, I adored her."
So did a nation. Thousands were expected to line the streets on April 5 for the ceremonial procession of her coffin from St. James's Palace to Westminster Hall, where her body will lie in state until April 9, when a funeral will be held at Westminster Abbey. As flags flew at half-staff, admirers signed condolence books and flocked to Buckingham Palace and the Queen Mum's London residence, Clarence House. To many she was an emblem of a more dignified age. "The royal family has had its sticky patches, but she stayed above it all," said Londoner Richard Dinkeldein, 57, who left a bouquet at Clarence House. "She had a sense of what royalty was supposed to be."
Indeed, she was probably the most beloved British royal of the 20th century, a Windsor throwback who unfailingly put the interests of the crown before all others, including her own. To be sure, she enjoyed her daily gin and Dubonnet, played the ponies avidly and displayed the occasional touch of regal hauteur: She had a way of forgetting to pay the couturiers who outfitted her, and she never forgave President Jimmy Carter for once kissing her. But as consort to King George VI, Elizabeth was indispensable in helping the monarchy ride out some of the most troubled chapters in modern British history.
Her husband was a reluctant ruler whose reign began in 1936 after his older brother David (King Edward VIII) shocked the world by renouncing the throne to marry the twice-divorced American Wallis Simpson. "An intolerable honor" was the way Elizabeth described her impending role. Concerned that her shy, stammering husband would be unequal to the stress of the job, she is said never to have forgiven "that woman," as she called Simpson. But with Elizabeth's support and encouragement, George rose magnificently to the task. During the terrible war years that followed, Elizabeth cemented her place in the chronicles of the kingdom by her courage in sharing her people's dangers and hardships. From then on, she could do no wrong.
Whenever the Queen Mum turned out in public—a tiny, 5'2", apple-cheeked figure swathed from head to toe in frothy, pastel-colored confections—the crowds did too. In recent years she would appear at the door of Clarence House at approximately 11:15 a.m. each Aug. 4, her birthday—even last year when her health was failing—to wave to assembled well-wishers as they broke into a heartfelt "Happy Birthday."
Although her public persona was as comfy as a tea cozy, privately the Queen Mum was the steely core of an increasingly troubled royal house. "She is a splendid old bird," one friend told her biographer Christopher Warwick. "There is never an iciness or sharpness, but...underneath the charm there is granite—the nicest sort of granite." When her family or their spouses strayed, that hardness showed through, beginning with her early ostracism of Mrs. Simpson. In the 1950s, when her daughter Princess Margaret sought—against Church of England rules—to marry a divorced man, RAF Group Capt. Peter Townsend, Elizabeth's frosty response helped doom the romance. As for her obstreperous, self-indulgent granddaughters-in-law, Elizabeth wound up supporting Prince Charles against Diana and helped in reining in Sarah, the Duchess of York, before the Yorks split in 1992. By the time Charles and Diana divorced in 1996, "the Queen Mother—in Diana's mind—was treating Diana like Wallis Simpson," the princess's friend Roberto Devorik told PEOPLE. Biographer Warwick concurs: "There was no great love lost between her and Princess Diana, but I think she would have been the first to offer a shoulder to William and Harry." Indeed, the young princes "liked to spend time with her," said the Queen Mum's great-niece Lady Elizabeth Shakerley, "because she was such fun."
Elizabeth's own childhood was idyllic. Born the Hon. Elizabeth Angela Marguerite Bowes Lyon, she was the ninth of 10 children of Viscount and Viscountess Glamis, later Earl and Countess of Strathmore. The family lived in St. Paul's Walden Bury, in Hertfordshire north of London. Victoria was still Queen when Elizabeth was born in 1900, and the Bowes Lyon household was a rare one for its time and class in that the children were both seen and heard. From an early age Elizabeth had a seemingly effortless knack for putting others at ease. Whenever her parents entertained and there was a lull in the conversation, the word went out, "Find Elizabeth."
Turning 14 on the day World War I began, Elizabeth was too young to assist in nursing but sang to hospitalized soldiers, helped them write letters, served meals and knitted mufflers, mittens and socks. Following the Allied victory, Elizabeth was swept up in the Roaring '20s and soon earned a reputation as "the best dancer in London." At a party, she was reintroduced to Prince Albert (known as Bertie and later to become King George VI), whom she had first met as a child.
Brought up in the shadow of his older brother David, a charmer and philanderer who had been groomed for the throne from the cradle, Bertie was comparatively deficient in the social graces. Plagued by awkward speech and an occasional temper, the insecure 27-year-old prince had to struggle to persuade Elizabeth-then 22 and not eager to settle down-to marry him. But the Queen Mum later gallantly quashed the rumor that he had to propose three times before she accepted. "Now look at me," she said. "Do you think I am the sort of person Bertie would have to ask twice?"
The couple married in Westminster Abbey in 1923, and in the first public display of her ability to connect with the common folk, Elizabeth impulsively and touchingly placed her wedding bouquet on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier inside the Abbey. Prince Albert had been created Duke of York in 1920, and upon her marriage Elizabeth became Duchess of York. Because the heir apparent, David, was a bachelor, Albert and Elizabeth shouldered a large share of royal duties, and Elizabeth found her every move tracked in the press. Her favored Scottish tartans came back in fashion, as did another sartorial trademark, fox-trimmed coats.
Elizabeth was equally masterful offstage. She worked with Albert—and a speech therapist—to bring his stammer under control. The birth of two daughters, Elizabeth in 1926 and Margaret Rose four years later, completed their partnership. Then, in 1936, King George V, Albert's father, died, and David became King Edward VIII. By then the new monarch, whose weakness for married women was well-known, was intoxicated with the wily Mrs. Simpson. Forced by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin to choose between his heritage and heart, Edward chose the seductress from Baltimore. He abdicated after 362 days.
After his own coronation at Westminster Abbey in May 1937, the new King, who took the name George VI, and Elizabeth made a surprise tour of the slums of North London and were cheered enthusiastically. He and his Queen Consort vowed they would "do the best that we can." And they did magnificently, particularly in their finest hour and sternest test, World War II. Biographer Warwick records that from 1939 to 1945 the royal couple made 300 trips within Great Britain, covering some 40,000 miles, to exhort the troops and factor)'-workers and comfort survivors in the rubble and devastation. But of all her wartime deeds, the Queen's decision to keep young Elizabeth and Margaret at Windsor Castle, just 20 miles outside London, was perhaps the most meaningful to British families. Her now famous response to pleas to send the girls overseas to safety: "The children could not leave without me, I could not leave without the King, and the King will never leave."
In September 1940 Buckingham Palace was bombed three times in a period of eight days, causing extensive damage to the family's private quarters. Referring to London's working-class neighborhoods, leveled by German bombs during the Blitz, the Queen was reported to have said, "Now I can look the East End in the face."
By V-E Day in 1945, the couple were lionized as heroes, but the stress of war took its toll on the King's already dicey health. He was a heavy smoker and in 1951 was diagnosed with lung cancer. Elizabeth's beloved Bertie finally died in his sleep on Feb. 6,1952, at 56; that same day, her daughter ascended the throne as Elizabeth II.
The elder Elizabeth's work ethic never waned. As the Queen Mother, she was patron of 300 charities, honorary colonel of 18 British regiments and commandant in chief of all three women's military services. Hip replacements in 1995 and 1998 and, shortly after she turned 100, a broken collarbone, limited her mobility. But for years before that, Elizabeth and Margaret had implored their mother to ease her schedule. Her famous retort: "Your work is the rent you pay for the room you occupy on earth."
A true merry widow, she was no slacker at fun either. She loved to host lavish lunches for an eclectic mix of friends, and even in her final years occasionally stayed out until the wee hours. At the 1999 wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones, she was seen throwing aside her walking sticks and doing the Twist on the dance floor. (British actor Anthony Andrews, who was there, said the Queen put a stop to it by stamping her feet and pleading: "Come on Mummy, it's time for bed.") A keen racing fan, the Queen Mum owned about 10 horses at any given time, and over the years her mounts won 460 races and collected considerable prize money. She was accomplished at fly-fishing and taught Prince Charles—said to have been her favorite grandchild—to fish at Balmoral in Scotland.
As the sun set on the British Empire, Elizabeth could be unreservedly toasted as the last and best of a now departed breed. More than that, said Prince Charles, speaking for a nation in the days after her death, "she was, quite simply, the most magical grandmother you could possibly have."
With reporting from Nina Biddle, Eileen Finan and Simon Perry in London
